docs.title: How We Invest: Ethics Come First
Our Technical Position
docs.text:
Our process starts with rigorous ethical screening as the first step, then applies sophisticated financial analysis to build concentrated portfolios (<20 holdings) of businesses where positive impact and revenue generation are inseparable. We combine bottom-up company research with top-down thematic analysis, structured around four verticals: Infrastructure, Innovation, Lending, and Real Estate. This isn't about collecting companies that sound ethical—it's about building portfolios aligned with genuine ethical frameworks.

{% include "partials/faq-highlights.html" %}

docs.title: Core Principles
docs.text:
All of our investment strategies share these foundational elements:

  • Ethics-First Approach. We start with what's right, not what's fashionable or convenient.
  • Concentrated Portfolios. Good ideas are hard to find—we don't dilute the ones we have with hundreds of mediocre holdings.
  • Revenue Is Impact. We strive to identify investment opportunities where revenue generation and positive impact are inseparable.
  • Evolving Portfolio Principles. We continuously weed out problematic companies as they find new ways to disappoint us, treating ethical screening as ongoing gardening, not a one-time checklist.
  • Transparency About Limitations. We're honest about being "wrong about 15%" of ethical assessments and commit to learning when we miss something.

The principles below provide additional support to our investment process:

  • Humility is irreplaceable. Hubris hurts clients, and has no place here.
  • Investing isn't speculation. If we can't tell what's what, it's a problem.
  • Costs kill compounding. Avoiding expenses is the easiest way to create value.
  • Simplicity is sophisticated. Complex frameworks are for architects, not investors.
  • Many things can be true at once. The market operates with more than one mindset.
  • Change is slow, then sudden. Innovation needs space and time to mature.

docs.title: 1. Defining Our Investable Universe: The Evolving Portfolio Principles
docs.text:
Unlike set-and-forget ethical screens, our approach treats ethical screening like tending a garden—continuously cultivating and weeding out problematic companies through ongoing research, collaboration with expert organizations, and adaptation to emerging ethical concerns. Companies constantly innovate new ways to be problematic, defeating static ethical screens.

Our rigorous screening process establishes clear boundaries:

  • We exclude questionable issuers to concentrate our research on viable companies
  • Common exclusion criteria include:
  • Direct harm to living things
  • Unacceptable emissions and environmental practices
  • Human rights violations
  • Poor governance structures
  • Business practices contradictory to ethical values

This thorough screening allows us to build an investable universe of companies that meet our baseline ethical criteria before proceeding to more detailed analysis.

Learn more about our comprehensive Screening Policy

docs.title: 2. Revenue Is Impact: Evaluating Investment OpportunitiesPeopleProductExecutionValuationMoatRisk
docs.text:
Our "Revenue Is Impact" philosophy is applied most comprehensively in our Growth strategy, which selects companies that generate positive impact through their core business activities. This creates an inseparable link between financial success and ethical outcomes, fundamentally different from companies doing good with profits after harmful business activities.

While this philosophy guides all our strategies, we recognize that different strategies may require different applications of this principle. Our Diversifying Allocation strategy, for instance, takes a more pragmatic approach when incorporating external managers.

We score each security that passes our screening process on wide-ranging criteria across six key areas:

Do great people want to work here?

  • Effective governance structures
  • Distinctive corporate culture
  • Retention of diverse staff
  • Leadership quality and integrity
  • Fair compensation practices

Do they make something people want?

  • Vision for future innovation
  • Market share growth
  • Focus on appropriate KPIs
  • Positive societal impact
  • Sustainable product lifecycle

Are they getting things done?

  • Returns on R&D investments
  • Effective sales and marketing
  • Improving operational results
  • Quality financial management
  • Adaptability to change

Can we buy at a reasonable price?

  • Fundamental metrics (P/E, P/B)
  • Sensible asset valuations
  • Free cash flow generation
  • Debt levels and structure
  • Margin and profitability trends

Is their progress protected?

  • Risk of disruption
  • Competitive pressure
  • Community engagement
  • Intellectual property strength
  • Network effects

What could go wrong?

  • Adoption risk
  • Regulatory and geopolitical risk
  • Potential capital loss
  • ESG concerns
  • Industry-specific challenges

docs.title: 3. Concentration Amplifies Conviction: Portfolio Construction
docs.text:
Our concentrated approach (<20 companies in our flagship portfolio) enables deep research into each holding, ensuring genuine ethical alignment and financial quality rather than superficial screening. Most ethical funds own hundreds of companies, diluting impact and making true ethical assessment impossible.

Our portfolio construction process:

  1. We select from the highest-scoring securities in our investable universe
  2. Position sizing is derived directly from our scoring process
  3. We regularly re-evaluate scores for each security to ensure continued alignment
  4. We maintain diversification across our four verticals
  5. We adapt portfolio allocations based on market conditions and valuation opportunities

docs.title: 4. Beyond Ethical Vibes: Our Investment Strategies
docs.text:
We don't invest based on what "sounds good" rather than what does good. Our portfolio often includes unexciting but ethically sound businesses with strong cash flows and real-world impact, distinguishing us from competitors who invest based on ethical vibes rather than substance.

Unlike funds that collect companies with sci-fi sounding names and weak fundamentals, we focus on businesses that can deliver sustainable impact through proven models. We don't need futuristic promises when we can find companies making a positive difference today through their core operations.

docs.title: The Cognitive Harmony Advantage
docs.text:
For long-term investors, aligning your portfolio with your values isn't just morally consistent—it's practically essential. When you plan to hold investments for decades, the last thing you want is growing ethical discomfort or the psychological gymnastics of justifying problematic holdings.

Our clients report visible stress reduction during meetings when discussing their portfolios because:

  • There's no need for defensive justifications about holdings
  • They experience coherence between values and financial actions
  • Their investments contribute to the world they want to create, not undermine it

This cognitive harmony creates a sustainable commitment to investment strategy regardless of market conditions, as your conviction is rooted in values alignment, not just return chasing.

docs.title: Screening Policy: Our Evolving Portfolio Principles
Continuous Vigilance, Not Set-and-Forget
docs.text:
We treat ethical screening like tending a garden—constantly weeding out problematic companies through ongoing research, collaboration with expert organizations, and adaptation to emerging ethical concerns. Companies constantly innovate new ways to be problematic, defeating static ethical screens.

Our screening policy isn't a one-time checklist or a marketing exercise—it's a living document that establishes the rigorous ethical framework guiding all our investment decisions. It defines clear criteria for excluding companies from our investment universe, ensuring that our portfolios align with genuine ethical principles, not just superficial ESG metrics.

Unlike most firms, we acknowledge the inherent limitations and complexities of ethical investing. We're transparent about being "wrong about 15%" of ethical assessments—because real ethical investing means confronting these challenges honestly, not pretending they don't exist.

docs.text:

docs.title: Scope of the Screening Policy
docs.text:
1. These guidelines apply to all mandates managed by Ethical Capital regardless of asset class.
  2. Our Chief Investment Officer is charged with executing this policy, consulting with internal and external experts as needed.
  3. Final decision-making authority resides with our investment committee.
  4. Recommendations and decisions on exclusions based on subsections 2 and 3 shall not include:
  5. Green bonds issued by the company in question where such bonds are recognized through inclusion in specific indices for green bonds or are verified by an independent third party.
  6. Shareholdings where Ethical Capital sees mission-oriented opportunities such as a shareholder activism campaign or scope for constructive long-term engagement with management.
  7. Companies that have enacted changes in strategy, structure, or capital expenditure policy that will generate substantial positive impact.
  8. Decisions on the observation and exclusion of companies in portfolios are regularly reviewed, and may be revised at Ethical Capital's discretion.

docs.title: Criteria for Product-Based Exclusion of Companies under the Screening Policy
docs.text:
1. Assets entrusted to our firm shall not be invested in companies which themselves or through entities they control:
  2. Cause direct harm to living things, including through:
    1. Manufacturing meat, dairy, eggs, honey, butter, silk, and cheese,
    2. Contributing to demand for leathers, hides, and furs, or
    3. Production of fishing, hunting, and other equipment that directly harms animals.
    4. Sale of weapons, military materiel, or consulting services that support military operations,
  3. Prey on addictions to alcohol, tobacco, and gambling,
  4. Aid and abet the fossil fuel industry through lending, oilfield services, and other related services,
  5. Are principally and clearly engaged in extractive activities, including through mining, expropriation of public assets, or other activities which generate significant externalized costs,
  6. Enable and deepen surveillance capitalism through consumer tracking, privacy erosion, and related operations, or
  7. Operate for-profit prisons.
  8. Ethical Capital may decide to exclude or further observe companies which through themselves or entities they control:
  9. Derive 30% or more of their income from thermal coal,
  10. Base 30% or more of their operations on thermal coal,
  11. Extract more than 20 million tonnes of thermal coal per year, or
  12. Have a coal power capacity of more than 10,000 MW from thermal coal.
  13. Ethical Capital will also consider forward-looking assessments pursuant to subsection (2), since company plans may change the level of extraction, capacity, income, or share of overall revenues derived from renewable energy sources.

docs.title: Criteria for Conduct-Based Exclusion of Companies under the Screening Policy
docs.text:
Companies may be excluded or put under observation from all strategies managed by our firm if there is an unacceptable risk that the company contributes to or is responsible for:

  1. Direct harm to human and non-human animals, including through:
  2. Animal testing,
  3. Environmental practices,
  4. Hostile work environments,
  5. Neglect, or
  6. Other outcomes of business practices.
  7. Gross abuse of water resources,
  8. Inadequate respect & deference given to indigenous communities.
  9. Failure to adequately hire, retain, include, and promote diverse staff,
  10. Failure to adequately secure the company's information resources and/or invest in suitable technology infrastructure,
  11. Failure to provide appropriate oversight of all related activities (including failure to provide safe working conditions or protect consumers),
  12. Human rights violations, including murder, torture, deprivation of liberty, forced labor, and child labor,
  13. Serious violations of the rights of individuals in situations of war or conflict,
  14. Severe environmental damage,
  15. Acts or omissions that on an aggregate company level lead to unacceptable greenhouse gas emissions,
  16. Providing financial support to politicians or political parties that enact targeted restrictions on access to healthcare, employment, or other goods and services that might reasonably be considered essential.
  17. Engagement in schemes and other chicanery to avoid taxes in a manner that significantly departs from industry practices,
  18. Gross corruption,
  19. Anti-union behavior,
  20. Contravention of law,
  21. Predatory lending, or
  22. Other serious violations of fundamental ethical norms.

docs.title: Our Commitment to Transparency and Continuous Improvement
docs.text:
Our screening policy embodies our evolving portfolio principles—a continuous process of weeding out problematic companies as they find new ways to disappoint us. We conduct periodic reviews to ensure our policy remains effective and aligned with our mission, adapting to emerging ethical concerns and evolving business practices.

docs.text: We're delighted you've chosen to align your investments with your values. This guide introduces our approach and what you can expect during onboarding.

docs.title: Our Commitment to You
docs.text: At Ethical Capital, we build concentrated portfolios that authentically reflect your values. We focus on where companies make their money, not just how they operate, and maintain vigilant oversight as companies evolve over time. Our intersectional approach goes beyond surface-level vibes to provide substantive alignment you can understand and trust.

docs.title: Ethics-First, Always
docs.text: We are an ethics-first investment firm, not a returns-first firm with ethical considerations tacked on. Investment decisions begin with ethical alignment and then consider the fundamentals, never the reverse.

docs.title: Revenue Is Impact
docs.text: We believe a company's revenue sources are the clearest indicator of its real-world impact. Our analysis focuses on where companies make their money, not just how they operate, because revenue streams reveal a company's true priorities and impacts in the world.

docs.title: Concentration Amplifies Conviction
docs.text: We believe in concentrated portfolios because meaningful ethical alignment requires deep understanding. By focusing on fewer companies, we gain thorough knowledge of each holding, enabling genuine confidence in their alignment with your values.

Every meeting with us begins with a simple question: "What's going on and how can I help?" We believe in meeting you where you are, without judgment or expectations. There's no need to prepare extensively or present a polished financial picture - we're here to understand your authentic needs and concerns.

Your unique perspective, questions, and values are what make our relationship meaningful. Whether you're just beginning your financial journey or have complex existing investments, we start by listening to you.

docs.title: For Each Investor Persona
docs.text:
• For Values-First Individuals

    We provide genuine cognitive harmony by eliminating the dissonance between your values and your investments. Our concentrated portfolios enable complete transparency and peace of mind about your money's impact, reducing the stress that comes from wondering what your money is supporting. The result is investment pride rather than compromise, and visible stress reduction during portfolio discussions.

    Learn more

  • For Disillusioned Skeptics

    We acknowledge the complexities and limitations of ethical investing. We're refreshingly honest about being "wrong about 15%" of the time, continuously learning and adapting our approach as companies find new ways to disappoint us. No greenwashing, no marketing spin—just genuine effort and a commitment to substance over superficial ESG box-checking. We're for investors who demand real ethical rigor, not branded virtue signaling.

    Learn more

  • For Post-Divestment Activists

    We help you move beyond simply avoiding harm to creating positive impact. Our approach embraces intersectional ethics (BDS, animal rights, climate justice) while selecting companies where revenue generation directly creates positive impact—providing a bridge from divestment to constructive investment. Our revenue = impact framework ensures that the companies you own generate positive outcomes through their core business activities, not as side projects from harmful operations.

    Learn more

  • For LGBTQ+ Value Aligners

    Our queer-led firm naturally integrates intersectional ethical awareness, creating an investment experience where identity, values, and investments harmonize. We provide investment services that genuinely respect and understand your complete identity and community values. Our shared lived experience creates a natural understanding of marginalization and the importance of ethical consistency across all dimensions, from social justice to environmental responsibility.

    Learn more

  • For Institutional Pathfinders

    We provide the tools needed to implement genuine ethical investing at institutional scale: rigorous process documentation, a comprehensive ethical framework, and stakeholder communication tools. Our "living policy" approach to ethical screening offers complete transparency and defense against greenwashing accusations. We understand the challenges of balancing fiduciary duty with ethical mandates and provide a defensible, documented approach that satisfies even the most demanding stakeholders.

    Learn more

docs.title: Our Core Services
docs.text:
• Concentrated Portfolio Management

    Our flagship service offers concentrated portfolios (<20 holdings) where you can fully understand and believe in each investment. This approach enables deep research into each holding, ensuring genuine ethical alignment and financial quality rather than superficial screening. Most ethical funds own hundreds of companies, diluting impact and making true ethical assessment impossible.

    Learn more

  • Four Verticals Investment Framework

    We structure our investments around four key verticals that drive positive impact:

    • Infrastructure: Physical systems supporting sustainable communities
    • Innovation: Technologies solving critical problems
    • Lending: Ethical capital allocation supporting positive projects
    • Real Estate: Sustainable property development and management

    This framework ensures disciplined diversification while maintaining focus on high-impact areas where revenue generation is inseparable from positive outcomes.

    Learn more

  • Ethics-First Consultations

    We provide personalized financial strategy sessions focused on aligning your entire financial life with your values. These consultations consider not just investments, but banking, estate planning, charitable giving, and more—creating comprehensive alignment across all financial decisions. Our consultations eliminate the cognitive dissonance that comes from attempting to separate values from finances.

    Schedule a consultation

  • Beyond Ethical Vibes Screening

    Our rigorous research approach avoids "ethical-sounding" investments in favor of ethically sound businesses with strong cash flows and real-world impact. We don't fall for futuristic promises or flashy marketing—we invest in companies doing real good right now through their core business models. Unlike competitors who invest based on what "sounds good" rather than what does good, our portfolios often include unexciting but fundamentally ethical businesses.

    Learn about our screening policy

  • Living Ethics Framework

    Our ethical criteria evolve as companies change practices, with regular updates to our screening policy and ongoing ethical research to ensure continued alignment. We treat ethical screening like gardening—constantly weeding out problematic companies and adapting to emerging ethical concerns. This continuous vigilance distinguishes us from set-and-forget approaches that quickly become outdated as companies innovate new ways to be problematic.

    Learn about our framework

  • Wealth Beyond Money

    We help you achieve financial participation without ethical compromise, contributing to a positive-sum financial ecosystem where investment becomes an expression of your identity and values. By aligning your capital with your complete personal values, you contribute to market transformation while integrating financial and ethical wealth. This holistic approach recognizes that true wealth encompasses more than just financial returns.

    Contact us

docs.title: Infrastructure: The Rails and Roads that Connect Us
docs.text:
The earth is a huge place, but the right infrastructure can make it feel like one global village. We believe that the uniquely long-term nature of these businesses can make them excellent investments, and have dedicated a portion of this portfolio to them since inception.

Companies we have owned that typify this theme include:

  • Quanta Services (PWR) – Maintains and expands electric power infrastructure, taking many small steps towards a true smart grid
  • Badger Meter (BMI) – Builds water meters that send telemetry back to headquarters, improving water quality and reducing system cost
  • Vinci SA – A global construction and engineering concern that builds and operates road, rail, ports, and other key assets

docs.title: Lending: Banks that Fund Our Future
docs.text:
So much progress hinges on the availability of loans. These banks are positively enmeshed in their surrounding societies. We avoid predatory banks in part by looking closely at these linkages.

Companies we have owned that typify this theme include:

  • Amalgamated Bank (AMAL) – A bank built by labor organizers that's still at the forefront of social responsibility

Real estate is a vast industry that offers tremendous opportunity for impact. The real estate investments that interest us tend to be tied to a positive social system of some kind: whether they're serving a local community directly or delivering on a practical industry need.

Preferred stocks are hybrid securities that blend characteristics of stocks and bonds. They generally have the following differences from common stocks:

  • Higher dividends
  • No voting rights
  • Bought primarily for income (vs. appreciation)

When preferred stock is issued by companies we regard highly, we usually aren't as concerned about voting rights, as the income characteristics are the primary focus for this strategy.

docs.title: A Different Approach to Ethical Impact
docs.text: Our "Revenue Is Impact" philosophy represents a fundamental shift in how we think about ethical investing. Instead of focusing on companies that use a portion of their profits for good causes after potentially harmful business activities, we select companies where positive impact is inseparable from their core business model.

docs.title: The Key Distinction
docs.text: Conventional Approach Our Approach Revenue THEN ImpactCompanies generate revenue through various means, then use a portion of profits for good causes Revenue IS ImpactCompanies generate revenue BY creating positive outcomes, making impact inseparable from financial success An oil company funding carbon offset projects A company building essential infrastructure for renewable energy A fast fashion retailer with a sustainability initiative A clothing company with circular design and ethical manufacturing at its core A tech company with problematic business practices but strong charitable giving A tech company whose products inherently solve social or environmental problems

docs.title: Why This Matters
docs.text:
When a company's revenue is directly tied to positive impact:

  1. Impact Scales Naturally - As the business grows financially, its positive impact grows proportionally
  2. Aligned Incentives - Management doesn't face tradeoffs between profit and purpose
  3. Transparency - The ethical impact is visible in the business model, not hidden in corporate reports
  4. Resistance to Change - Companies are less likely to abandon their impact work during downturns
  5. Cognitive Harmony - Investors don't need to rationalize how their investments make money

docs.title: How We Apply This Principle
docs.text: This philosophy is applied most comprehensively in our Growth strategy, which represents our highest ethical conviction. Our other strategies, particularly our Diversifying Allocation strategy, take a more pragmatic approach while still maintaining strong ethical standards.

docs.title: Examples in Our Portfolio
docs.text: Here are examples of companies we've held that exemplify the Revenue Is Impact approach:

docs.title: Infrastructure
docs.text:
• Quanta Services (PWR) – Maintains and expands electric power infrastructure, taking many small steps towards a true smart grid
  • Badger Meter (BMI) – Builds water meters that send telemetry back to headquarters, improving water quality and reducing system cost

docs.title: Innovation
docs.text:
• Duolingo (DUOL) – The language learning app that democratizes education access globally
  • Nintendo (NTDOY) – A designer of innovative, family-friendly video games with better-than-average labor practices

docs.title: Lending
docs.text:
• Farmer Mac (AGM) – America's largest agricultural lender providing critical financing to rural communities
  • Amalgamated Bank (AMAL) – A bank founded by labor organizers that's still at the forefront of social responsibility

docs.title: Real Estate
docs.text:
• Alexandria Real Estate (ARE) – Provides specialized lab space that helps innovative biotech companies develop life-saving treatments
  • Armada Hoffler (AHH) – A developer of mixed-use urban communities, primarily in Baltimore and Virginia City

docs.title: Challenges and Limitations
docs.text:
We're transparent about the challenges of implementing this approach:

  • Perfect revenue-impact alignment is rare; we look for companies with the strongest alignment
  • Some sectors have limited options for pure Revenue Is Impact companies
  • Our assessment of impact is subjective and sometimes we're wrong
  • We continuously refine our understanding of what constitutes genuine impact
